questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not hepatotoxic?
questions.solution:
Cycloserine is not a hepatotoxic drug. The adverse effects of cycloserine are mainly neurological.

Half of the patients on cycloserine (1g/day) experience neuropsychiatric symptoms. It ranges from headaches to psychosis, seizures, and suicidal ideas. Therefore, cycloserine is contraindicated in patients with epilepsy.

Ethionamide, rifampicin, isoniazid and pyrazinamide are hepatotoxic agents. They are either contraindicated or used with extreme caution in hepatitis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who was started on treatment for MDR-TB 6 months back, presented with complaints of fatigue, amenorrhea, and constipation since the past 1 month. On examination, a swelling was noticed on the anterior aspect of her neck. Her lab reports show raised TSH levels with low free T3 and T4 levels. Which anti-tubercular drug is likely to cause this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and lab reports are suggestive of hypothyroidism with goiter, which is a known adverse effect of ethionamide.

MDR-TB is treated with 2nd line agents that include ethionamide (ETH). ETH is not a first-line agent due to its gastrointestinal side effects. It is structurally related to thionamides (propylthiouracil and methimazole) and therefore causes hypothyroidism by preventing organification of iodine in thyroid hormone synthesis. Another antitubercular drug that can cause hypothyroidism is Para-amino salicylic acid (PAS). 

ETH/PAS-induced hypothyroidism should be treated with thyroxine replacement therapy, instead of changing the regimen. Thyroid function usually optimizes within 2 months after completing MDR therapy.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of anti-mycobacterial action of bedaquiline?
questions.solution:
The mechanism of anti-mycobacterial action of bedaquiline is by inhibition of ATP synthase.

Bedaquiline is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with hypertension was diagnosed with drug-resistant pulmonary TB. One week after starting ATT he presented to the casualty following an episode of syncope. ECG showed a corrected QT interval of 477ms, which is shown below. Which drug used in his anti-tubercular therapy is responsible for this adverse effect?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with a corrected QT (QTc) interval of 477ms is suggestive of QTc prolongation which is an adverse effect associated with bedaquiline.

In the ECG QTc (corrected QT interval= QT/√RR) is 477ms. Normal QTc is about 440ms. Values of more than 440ms in males and 460ms in females are considered to be prolonged. QTc prolongation usually presents as syncope or cardiac arrest.

Although QT prolongation can cause Torsades de pointes, no cases have been reported with bedaquiline. A 5-fold higher rate of death has been reported in patients on bedaquiline versus those on placebo. Therefore, the World Health Organization (WHO) advises caution when administering this medication. Bedaquiline is contraindicated in the age group of <18 years.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of delamanid?
questions.solution:
Delamanid acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Pretomanid and delamanid are bicyclic nitroimidazoles that act by inhibiting mycolic acid (a component of the mycobacterial cell wall) and protein synthesis in the mycobacteria.

Pretomanid in combination with bedaquiline and linezolid was approved by FDA in 2019 for the treatment of adult patients with extensively drug-resistant (XDR) TB and for patients who are treatment-intolerant or nonresponsive to multidrug-resistant pulmonary (MDR) TB treatment.

In India, delamanid is only approved for the management of MDR-TB.

Isoniazid also acts by inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis.

Other options:

Option A: Bedaquiline acts by inhibition of ATP synthase. It is a diarylquinoline that targets the subunit c of the ATP synthase of M. tuberculosis. This leads to inhibition of the proton pump activity of the ATP synthase and causes a failure in the bacillary energy metabolism.

Option C: Fluoroquinolones act by inhibition of DNA gyrase. They are used as second-line agents in the treatment of tuberculosis.

Option D: Cycloserine is a D-alanine analogue used as a second-line drug for MDR-TB that acts by inhibition of alanine racemase. Alanine racemase converts L-alanine to D-alanine which is needed for the mycobacterial cell wall.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman was diagnosed with tuberculosis. Which of the following antitubercular drugs should not be used in her?
questions.solution:
Streptomycin should not be used for the treatment of TB in a pregnant patient as it can cause hearing loss in the newborn.

First-line treatment for tuberculosis in pregnancy is done with isoniazid(along with pyridoxine), rifampicin, ethambutol, and pyrazinamide.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient with a CD4 count of 40/mm3 requires prophylaxis against M. avium complex bacteremia. Which of the following drugs would you prefer?
questions.solution:
Azithromycin 1200 mg given once a week, is preferred for prophylactic therapy against bacteremia caused by Mycobacterium-avium complex (MAC) in people living with AIDS.

Clarithromycin 500 mg twice daily, may also be administered for prophylaxis. Rifabutin 300 mg once daily is used for patients who are intolerant to macrolides.

Prophylaxis is indicated when CD4 counts are less than 50/mm3 and should be discontinued once the CD4 count is more than 100/mm3. 

Dapsone is used as an alternative agent for prophylaxis of pneumocystis jirovecii infection, whereas isoniazid is used for prophylaxis of mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: An elderly woman on ART with a CD4 count of 35/μL and a high viral load presents with a 2 week history of cough, fever, and night sweats. She was diagnosed with pulmonary M. avium complex infection. Which of the following is not included in the triple-drug therapy for the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Triple drug therapy for pulmonary Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infections does not include isoniazid.

Treatment for pulmonary MAC infection is triple-drug therapy with:

  • A rifamycin, like rifampicin or rifabutin (In HIV patients on ART, rifabutin is preferred)
  • Ethambutol
  • A macrolide, like clarithromycin or azithromycin

MAC infection is an AIDS-defining opportunistic infection, occurring predominantly at CD4+ T cell counts of <50/μL and high viral load. The average CD4+ T cell count at the time of diagnosis is 10/μL. The most common presentation is disseminated disease with fever, weight loss, and night sweats.

questions.text: A patient undergoing treatment for TB developed resistance to rifampicin and isoniazid after 3 months. He can be treated with all the following drugs except __________.
questions.solution:
Tobramycin cannot be used in the treatment of MDR-TB (rifampicin and isoniazid resistant) as it is not considered a second-line antitubercular drug. 

Injectable aminoglycosides like amikacin, kanamycin, capreomycin, and fluoroquinolones like moxifloxacin and ofloxacin are second-line drugs used for treating MDR-TB.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: Which of the following beta lactam class has shown activity against MDR-TB?
questions.solution:
Carbapenems have shown activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Note: Until recently beta-lactams were assumed to lack action against Mycobacterium tuberculosis. However, carbapenems in conjunction with clavulanate have demosntrated efficacy against Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
